content.raw:
Could you explain this set of code? How is the new loadAccRange (with the first element only casted to a string) equivalent to

```python 
"0:%s" % last_window
```
?

content.raw: Specifically it would be great to see how the new loadAccRange is equivalent with `train_windows` when `self.minibatch_num_windows` is -1.
content.html: Specifically it would be great to see how the new loadAccRange is equivalent with train_windows when self.minibatch_num_windows is -1.

content.raw: There are two ways of specifying a list to GMTK: a range such as "3:8", or a comma-delimited list such as "3,4,5,6,7".  When `self.minibatch_num_windows` is 1, `train_windows` is `"0,1,2,...,last_window"`.
content.html: There are two ways of specifying a list to GMTK: a range such as "3:8", or a comma-delimited list such as "3,4,5,6,7". When self.minibatch_num_windows is 1, train_windows is "0,1,2,...,last_window".

content.html: This help text is double spaced when concatenated. Probably best to remove the initial whitespace on the last two lines.

content.html: Should remove "just a" from the initial sentence.

content.raw: "-1" is used as the value for the default number of windows for the minibatch. This should be placed in a named constant and replaced in the code accordingly.
content.html: "-1" is used as the value for the default number of windows for the minibatch. This should be placed in a named constant and replaced in the code accordingly.

content.raw: Fixed.
content.html: Fixed.

content.html: Is there any handling for the case where the self.minibatch_num_windows is greater than the number of training windows? Is that even possible?

content.raw: Checked in a fix for this case.  It will use all the windows in this case.
content.html: Checked in a fix for this case. It will use all the windows in this case.

content.raw: I don't think this description is especially clear. Many people using this will not already be familiar with the concept of "minibatch".
content.html: I don't think this description is especially clear. Many people using this will not already be familiar with the concept of "minibatch".

content.raw: It's not guaranteed to touch *every* genomic position but it will cover much more of the genome than using the same, say, 1% over and over again.
content.html: It's not guaranteed to touch every genomic position but it will cover much more of the genome than using the same, say, 1% over and over again.

content.raw:
@mlibbrecht, thanks for this addition. I think it will be very useful. The implementation looks fine but I am concerned about the interface--it's not totally friendly to have to set number of windows and `--split-sequences` like that, I'm not sure how it interacts with windows that are less than the max (say at the end of a chromosome or an `--include-coords` region and I think we are going to have some confused users.

What would you think instead of having the interface like `--minibatch-fraction=FRAC` instead. `FRAC` would be a number between 0.0 and 1.0 indicating how much of the selected training region (default: the whole genome). You would store that integer number of bases in a variable. Then you would keep adding random windows until you got to that fraction of the genome, rather than just a particular number of windows. Making sure to compare against integer number of bases would reduce any numerical problems you might get from comparing with fractions that might lead to never getting to 1.0.
content.html:
@mlibbrecht, thanks for this addition. I think it will be very useful. The implementation looks fine but I am concerned about the interface--it's not totally friendly to have to set number of windows and --split-sequences like that, I'm not sure how it interacts with windows that are less than the max (say at the end of a chromosome or an --include-coords region and I think we are going to have some confused users.

What would you think instead of having the interface like --minibatch-fraction=FRAC instead. FRAC would be a number between 0.0 and 1.0 indicating how much of the selected training region (default: the whole genome). You would store that integer number of bases in a variable. Then you would keep adding random windows until you got to that fraction of the genome, rather than just a particular number of windows. Making sure to compare against integer number of bases would reduce any numerical problems you might get from comparing with fractions that might lead to never getting to 1.0.

content.raw: I switched to the --minibatch-fraction interface as you suggested.
content.html: I switched to the --minibatch-fraction interface as you suggested.

@mlibbrecht I see you merged but with an older commit of the default branch: 0a29928. There was a recent pull request that changes optparse to argparse and changes to --split-sequences that needs to be merged in with your changes.

You can see this visually on: #!/hoffmanlab/segway/commits/all

A merge with the latest commit on the default branch is needed (or really any commit past e4b6b64).

content.raw: Merged.
content.html: Merged.

content.raw:
@mlibbrecht oddly there was some merge conflicts still but I've fixed them as well as fixed reported errors from Pyflakes. Notably I removed `last_window` in `queue_train_bundle` since it wasn't used. Is this correct?

I also ran simpleseg and found that test did not pass. Notably in the parameters to GMTK when running gmtkEMTrain this change outputs "-loadAccRange 0" instead of an expected "-loadAccRange 0:0". I'm 99% certain these are functionally equivalent - can you confirm?
content.html:
@mlibbrecht oddly there was some merge conflicts still but I've fixed them as well as fixed reported errors from Pyflakes. Notably I removed last_window in queue_train_bundle since it wasn't used. Is this correct?

I also ran simpleseg and found that test did not pass. Notably in the parameters to GMTK when running gmtkEMTrain this change outputs "-loadAccRange 0" instead of an expected "-loadAccRange 0:0". I'm 99% certain these are functionally equivalent - can you confirm?

content.raw:
Probably should specify these are positions across the entire input dataset (unless I'm mistaken). Does this option explicitly ignore --include-coords and --exclude-coords?
Users are also not going to know what "EM" means in this context - "for each training round" might be more helpful.
content.html: Probably should specify these are positions across the entire input dataset (unless I'm mistaken). Does this option explicitly ignore --include-coords and --exclude-coords? Users are also not going to know what "EM" means in this context - "for each training round" might be more helpful.

content.raw: No, it's as a fraction of the positions after include-coords and exclude-coords are taken into account.  Feel free to change the wording if you think you can make it clearer.
content.html: No, it's as a fraction of the positions after include-coords and exclude-coords are taken into account. Feel free to change the wording if you think you can make it clearer.

content.html: The Segway documentation explicitly defines the term "window" and uses it in many places throughout.

content.raw:
@mlibbrecht I've ran more tests and specifically when I ran into a test with mulitple windows, specifically the "mulitpledatasets" test I found a discrepancy in `loadAccRange` again and I'm not sure if the changes are equivalent.

Namely this change produces this for gmtkEMTrain:

`-loadAccRange 1,0` 

Before it was this:

`-loadAccRange 0:1`

These do not *look* equivalent but it might be something GMTK-specific that I'm unaware of. I'm also not sure if ordering is important in this case.
content.html:
@mlibbrecht I've ran more tests and specifically when I ran into a test with mulitple windows, specifically the "mulitpledatasets" test I found a discrepancy in loadAccRange again and I'm not sure if the changes are equivalent.

Namely this change produces this for gmtkEMTrain:

-loadAccRange 1,0

Before it was this:

-loadAccRange 0:1

These do not look equivalent but it might be something GMTK-specific that I'm unaware of. I'm also not sure if ordering is important in this case.

content.raw: As defined around run.py:1964, this patch changes the loadAccRange parameter from a range ("0:N") to a comma-delimited list ("0,1,...").  GMTK parses a range of "0:4" into the list "0,1,2,3,4". The order is not important.
content.html: As defined around run.py:1964, this patch changes the loadAccRange parameter from a range ("0:N") to a comma-delimited list ("0,1,..."). GMTK parses a range of "0:4" into the list "0,1,2,3,4". The order is not important.

content.raw: I've updated all the tests to include the new loadAccRange notation. All tests pass.
content.html: I've updated all the tests to include the new loadAccRange notation. All tests pass.
